title: Are empaths real or a myth? - Quora

response.answer_text: The term "empath" is science fiction term first used in an episode of Star Trek. So, from a clinical standpoint, there is no such thing as an empath, at least not in the way it is often described here. It's possible to be extremely empathetic so many people would consider themselves an "empath" in that respect. However, often searched much differently in this forum. In this context, "Empaths" believe they feel emotions at a deeper level than others, in turn making them more sensitive to the feelings of others. Some people even feel they experience the feelings of others in an almost literal sense. This is actually not that unusual - a lot of people are empathetic to the extent that they'll cry when someone else is sad, or feel genuinely happy when they see joy in someone else. This is affect empathy. Some have less of this and more cognitive empathy- a high ability to imagine themselves in someone else's shoes. These people are less judgemental and genuinely understand the behavior of others even if they don't agree with it. They may seem less empathetic to others but they're not - it's just a different type (and the one most obviously lacking in people with autism). As for the energy, I hear people say they feel a certain energy when someone enters a room all the time. They may or may not experience it in the literal sense, but it feels that way nonetheless. This is also very common - highly sensitive people will notice more, less sensitive people will notice less. What people who consider themselves "empaths" may have that others don't, is a hyper-sensitivity (or hypervigilance) that makes them more attuned to subtleties in facial expression, body language and tone of voice. This could be a response to trauma where the nervous system works overtime causing one to be in an almost constant state of fight or flight. This high attunement to other people ultimately leads to a preoccupation with them. That and a lack of boundaries can make relationships difficult and even painful. The attention/validation "empaths" require to maintain a self esteem is exhausting for many people but very attractive to narcissists. "Empaths" may consider themselves such because it helps them make sense of how they perceive and respond to the world. Is it an accurate perception? It's not my place to say how one perceives their experiences, and a person can call themselves whatever they want. The problem lies in a potential denial of reality and the attributing of such experiences to a metaphysical gift.

Empaths are very much real. Everyone has empathy is some extent or another. It is so ubiquitous that not having empathy results in being labeled with some pretty serious mental illnesses. An 'empath' is simple someone whose naturally sense of empathy is greater that usual. People often talk about the 'energy of a room' or how draining it is to spend time with someone suffering from depression. Comments like these are all within the realm of empathy. For an empath, moments like above are a daily occurance. They are picking up on emotions and energy levels of everyone around them all the time. Their sense of empathy is like a finely tuned and sensative instrument. Empathy is not metaphysical. It is not the same as clairvoyance or precognition or any of that. The idea that it is most likely arised from low empathy individuals perceiving an empath has having knowedge they could not possibly have, or from empaths themselves trying to inflate their own sense of importance.

Yes, we are real. And what’s more, we can recognize other empaths. We can also recognize sociopaths and other personality-disordered individuals with practice. We can tell when most people are lying and when most people are telling the truth. That’s one reason we attract very skilled sociopaths. They are trying to hone their skills. And they do seem to recognize us. I can fool her! That’s a very interesting game for them to play. We attract a lot of them, so we have a lot of practice. We know what animals feel. What little children feel. We can feel it. My favorite empath moment in recent years is I was talking to a woman I had just met. Actually it was a phone call set up by a man who knew us both. I said, “I have to tell you I was dreading this call.” She said, “I was, too.” I said, “Are you an emotional empath?” She said, “Well, yes, I am. How did you know?” I said, “I am an emotional empath.”

I believe empaths are probably real, but based on some evidence and speculation it’s safe to say that a lot of “empaths” are actually child abuse and domestic abuse survivors with some ptsd or other disorder caused by the abuse. They have a heightened sense of awareness and have learned to identify facial expressions and voice tone to change their behavior to avoid punishment or shame from the abusers. This was a defense mechanism to avoid more emotional/physical abuse. I cannot say this for all people who identify as empaths, but probably around 40 to 45% of them.
